üõ•Ô∏è A Home on the Water

Read the interview and check your understanding

Interviewer: Tell me about your home, Melanie.

Melanie: It's a canal boat. It's in Stratford-upon-Avon, Shakespeare's birthplace. But I often travel with the boat. I'm an artist and the boat is a fantastic place for painting.

Interviewer: Is it a quiet life?

Melanie: Yes, usually there aren't many boats on the canals. But in the summer, it's often very busy and noisy!

Interviewer: How many rooms are there on your boat?

Melanie: Not many! The boat is quite small so I haven't got many rooms. There are three. There isn't much space for my things.

Interviewer: How many bedrooms are there?

Melanie: There's one. But it's a living room and a bedroom. And I've got a kitchen and a bathroom, too.

Interviewer: How much furniture have you got?

Melanie: Not much but I've got a lot of clothes! And there are my paintings!

Interviewer: Have you got a lot of paintings?

Melanie: Yes, a lot! Hundreds!

Grammar Focus ‚úèÔ∏è

Expressing Quantity: much, many, a lot of

1. Countable Nouns (things you can count: boats, rooms, apples)

Use many and a lot of
üîä "There are a lot of canal boats in Stratford."
üîä "Usually there aren't many boats on the canals."

2. Uncountable Nouns (things you can't count: space, time, water)

Use much and a lot of
üîä "There's a lot of space in this room."
üîä "There isn't much space for my things."

3. Types of Sentences

‚úÖ Positive Sentences

Use a lot of.

üîä "I've got a lot of clothes."
‚ùå Negative Sentences

Use not many, not much, or not a lot of.

üîä "I haven't got many rooms."
‚ùì Questions

Use How many or How much.

üîä "How many bedrooms are there?"
üîä "How much furniture have you got?"
